user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_SetDeferredRetcode:
```c
void UT_SetDeferredRetcode(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 Count, UT_IntReturn_t Retcode)
{
    /* The count should always be a positive integer, if not there is a bug in the test */
    if (Count <= 0)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("BUG: Invalid Count (%ld) passed to UT_SetDeferredRetcode()", (long)Count);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(FuncKey, &Retcode, sizeof(Retcode), UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, Count, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_SetDeferredRetcode:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef ptrdiff_t UT_IntReturn_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
...
void UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize,
                                        UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre, int32 Counter, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_EntryType_t       ReqEntryType;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);

    /*
     * For deferred retval configs, this always adds a new entry.  But
     * for constant retval configs, it should replace the existing entry if
     * there is one.
     */
    if (Counter > 0)
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED;
        StubPtr      = NULL;
    }
    else
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT;
        StubPtr      = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, ReqEntryType);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot configure return value - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else
    {
        StubPtr->FuncKey = FuncKey;

        StubPtr->EntryType         = ReqEntryType;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Genre    = ValueGenre;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter  = Counter;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.ActualSz = ValueSize;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.TypeName = TypeName;

        if (ValueGenre == UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE)
        {
            /* For "unknown" types the pointer is stored directly - this allows for ANY return type of ANY size,
             * but requires that the caller maintain the buffer in scope until the test completes */
            StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf.IndirectPtr = ValuePtr;
        }
        else
        {
            /* For any of the recognized typical return types, a copy is made and stored in the state buffer */
            UT_StoreRetval(&StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf, ValuePtr, ValueSize, ValueGenre);
        }
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions were found in the provided code. The items that might superficially look like extensions are in fact standard C constructs: 
- The UtAssert_Failed macro uses __VA_ARGS__; variadic macros are part of standard C (since C99), not a compiler-specific extension. 
- Types such as ptrdiff_t, size_t, int32_t are standard C typedefs (from <stddef.h>/<stdint.h>), and the project typedefs (cpuaddr, UT_EntryKey_t, UT_IntReturn_t, int32) are ordinary aliases, not language extensions. 
- NULL, casts (e.g. (long)Count), function prototypes and pointer usage are standard C. 
- There are no inline assembler blocks, no GCC/Clang attributes (e.g. __attribute__), no typeof or statement-expressions, no designated-initializer extensions, no variable-length arrays, no implicit function declarations, and no other known vendor-specific keywords or constructs present. 
Given Rule 1.2 (report only explicit compiler extensions), nothing in these fragments requires investigation for language-extension usage.
